habitat_description:
Southwest:
NatureServe (2015) ranks habitat for the San Joaquin kangaroo rat in decreasing favorability: “(1) level to gently sloping areas with sparse to moderate shrub cover in alkali desert scrub and valley grassland, (2) ridgetops and steep slopes with sandy, friable soils and scattered shrubs in alkali desert scrub and valley grassland, (3) sandy arroyos and dry stream beds in above associations, and (4) arid annual grasslands with alkaline, friable soils.” In general, this species inhabits arid, alkaline plains of saltbush, grasses, and herbs, Mormon tea, and xerophylic shrubs (Wilson and Ruff 1999). This species has an altitudnal range of 50 to 800 meters (Grinnell 1933, Best 1991).
The subspecies D. n. nitratoides occupies valley saltbrush scrub and valley sink scrub communities on high salinity, alluvial fan, and floodplain soils ranging from fine sands to clay-sized particles (USFWS 1998). Typically, occupied habitats exist on level- to nearly-level terrain. Although Tipton kangaroo rats occur in terrace grasslands devoid of woody shrubs, sparse-to-moderate shrub cover is associated with populations of high density.
The Fresno kangaroo rat subspecies occupies habitat on elevated grassy patches on alkali plains or in grassy terrain with scattered alkali patches. Both habitat types are characterized by friable soils suitable for excavating burrow complexes (Culbertson 1946). They are typically associated with sandy and saline soils in chenopod scrub and annual grasslands, alkali sink communities and areas subject to seasonal inundation. Associated plant species include seepweed, iodine bush, saltbush, peppergrass, filaree, wild oats, and mouse-tail fescue (Culbertson 1946, Hoffmann 1974, Hoffmann and Chesemore 1982, USFWS 1998).
